abstract: John Solomon, a Newsweek reporter who interviewed Mr. Strauss-Kahn's accuser, will write a book for St. Martin's Press.
snippet: John Solomon, a Newsweek reporter who interviewed Mr. Strauss-Kahn's accuser, will write a book for St. Martin's Press.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Strauss-Kahn has left New York for Paris, but the story of his sexual encounter with a hotel chambermaid, and the criminal case that developed and then was dropped, is just reaching book publishers. St. Martin's Press, part of Macmillan, said on Monday it had acquired a book by John Solomon, the Newsweek reporter who interviewed Nafissatou Diallo, the housekeeper who accused Mr. Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault in May. Mr. Solomon's book "will report the inside story of how the DSK case was transformed from a slam-dunk, five-day indictment against Strauss-Kahn to a flat-out dismissal that turned the tables on his very accuser," a statement from the publisher said. The charges against Mr. Strauss-Kahn -- who called the encounter "an error'' and a "moral failure'' but not a criminal act -- were dismissed in August after prosecutors said the accuser lacked credibility.
